title: What to Do With Freezer Burned Food: Your Questions Answered

steps.title: Yes, freezer burned food is safe to eat.
steps.content: Yes, freezer burned food is safe to eat. Freezer burn only affects how a food tastes, but it doesn’t mean it’s gone bad. Freezer burn may also change the texture of the food, which can result in some less-than-stellar meal times. [1] X Trustworthy Source Food Safety and Inspection Service of the USDA Food safety information provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Go to source Freezer burn may also lower the nutritional value of the food you’re eating.

steps.title: Cut off any freezer burned sections.
steps.content: Cut off any freezer burned sections. You can usually tell meat has been freezer burned by looking for gray, discolored portions. Use a knife to cut off those sections and throw them away. [2] X Research source If the entire cut of meat has been freezer burned, don’t worry about cutting anything off. You can try to mask the taste with the steps below, or you can throw the entire piece out, since it may not taste great.

steps.title: Cook the meat into a soup or stew.
steps.content: Cook the meat into a soup or stew. Cooking a soup or making a stew is the perfect way to mask that freezer burned taste. Throw in some chicken or beef broth, your veggies of choice, and lots of herbs and spices. The abundance of flavors will counteract that less-than-ideal freezer burned taste. [3] X Research source Try a beef stew or a chicken and sweet potato stew for a chilly fall evening.

steps.title: Mask the freezer burned taste with a marinade or sauce.
steps.content: Mask the freezer burned taste with a marinade or sauce. If you’re working with beef or chicken, try marinating it in a flavorful marinade before cooking it. If you’re making fish, whip up a fresh garlic sauce to mask any unsavory flavors. [4] X Research source Fish absorbs flavor from sauces very easily, which is why this hack works so well.

steps.title: Cut away any portions that are freezer burned.
steps.content: Cut away any portions that are freezer burned. For larger vegetables, like broccoli, carrots, or squash, you may be able to see the freezer burned areas. If so, cut those portions off with a sharp knife. [5] X Trustworthy Source Food Safety and Inspection Service of the USDA Food safety information provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Go to source With smaller vegetables and fruits, it may be harder to tell. Try throwing away any of the vegetables that look the most freezer burned.

steps.title: Rinse and dehydrate fruits.
steps.content: Rinse and dehydrate fruits. If you notice that your fruit has small ice crystals on it, run it under cool water to rinse off the freezer burn. You can also cut your fruit up into small pieces and use a food dehydrator to dehydrate your fruit and make it taste great. [6] X Research source Or, dry fruit on a baking tray in the oven.

steps.title: Blend the fruits and veggies into a smoothie.
steps.content: Blend the fruits and veggies into a smoothie. Throw your fruits into the smoothie whole, or puree vegetables and add them in. Load up your smoothie with plenty of other flavors and spices to mask the taste of the freezer burn. [7] X Trustworthy Source Food Safety and Inspection Service of the USDA Food safety information provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Go to source Throw your freezer burned berries into a berry smoothie . Or, try something a little healthier with a green smoothie. You can also stir fry vegetables or throw them into a soup or stew.

steps.title: Use your bread in French toast.
steps.content: Use your bread in French toast. Soaking the bread in milk and eggs will rehydrate it and mask that freezer burn taste and texture. Make a batch of French toast for a delicious way to use up that freezer burned bread. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Make bread crumbs.
steps.content: Make bread crumbs. Let your bread thaw first, or use it frozen. Grind your bread in a food processor to make delicious bread crumbs that you can add to pasta or use to coat chicken breast. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Scoop out any freezer burned parts of the ice cream.
steps.content: Scoop out any freezer burned parts of the ice cream. Ice cream typically only develops freezer burn on the very top. To avoid eating any freezer burned portions, use a knife or a spoon to scrape off the top layer and throw it away.

steps.title: Freezer burn is a chemical reaction that happens when ice becomes gas.
steps.content: Freezer burn is a chemical reaction that happens when ice becomes gas. Through a process called sublimation, the moisture on the food becomes gas without melting and evaporating first, which leaves behind tiny ice crystals on your food. [10] X Research source Usually, freezer burn happens when food is exposed to air inside of the freezer.

steps.title: Wrap food up tightly before putting it in the freezer.
steps.content: Wrap food up tightly before putting it in the freezer. Most of the time, food gets freezer burned when it’s packaged incorrectly. Be sure to double wrap any food that you put into the freezer, and squeeze out as much air as you can beforehand to prevent freezer burn. Use aluminum foil, sealable bags, or plastic wrap for best results. [11] X Trustworthy Source Food Safety and Inspection Service of the USDA Food safety information provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Go to source You can also vacuum seal your food.

steps.title: Set your freezer to the lowest temperature.
steps.content: Set your freezer to the lowest temperature. When a freezer gets too warm, freezer burn is more likely to occur. Be sure your freezer remains steady at 0 °F (−18 °C) for best results. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Keep your freezer shut as much as possible.
steps.content: Keep your freezer shut as much as possible. Opening your freezer too often can cause temperature fluctuations, leading to freezer burn. Try not to open your freezer too often, and shut the door quickly whenever you do open it. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Only thaw your food once.
steps.content: Only thaw your food once. Refreezing your food increases the likelihood of freezer burn (plus, it can introduce dangerous bacteria to your food). Try not to thaw your food more than once for best results. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Use frozen food quickly.
steps.content: Use frozen food quickly. The longer your food sits inside the freezer, the more likely it is to develop freezer burn. While most food can last inside of the freezer indefinitely, try to eat your food within 3 years of freezing it for the best taste and texture. [15] X Research source
